hero.title: Room for All
hero.subtitle: Addressing the Affordable Housing Shortage Through Zoning Changes

intro.value: The United States has a housing affordability problem. The housing market has inadequate supply to meet the demands of a growing population, with an estimated shortage of 3.8 million houses for rent or sale in 2019. Zoning ordinances implemented by local governments sometimes hinder new development, contributing to rising home prices and ballooning rents nationwide.

body.value: Many cities across the nation are already exploring these types of changes in the face of continued obstacles to construction in the zoning code. In Washington DC, 36 percent of residential land is zoned for single-family homes exclusively, and much of this land—such as the in-demand Northwest portion of the city—is within easy access of subway stations, ideal neighborhoods for denser construction. In 2021, DC passed a comprehensive plan for zoning reform, which seeks to increase the available housing density 15 percent by 2025. And in Washington state, A and B zoning reforms were passed this spring.

But to address the full scope of the housing shortage, more changes are needed. Policymakers can target zoning changes near public transit stations to encourage more affordable housing by decreasing future residents’ transportation costs. They can reduce costs even further by eliminating parking requirements for new developments.

Making these changes may raise concerns from residents. In Nashville for example, a recent redevelopment proposal would build 480 apartments on the site of an under-utilized business center. But in a resident townhall, some locals noted their opposition because they felt the plans didn’t incorporate enough parking and feared more units would lead to more traffic. Evidence suggests that parking is routinely oversupplied because of zoning requirements—and that new development doesn’t have to lead to more traffic if it is accompanied with robust transit options.

Below, we display how the four zoning changes we explored above could expand potential housing development near transit in the Puget Sound region—including Seattle and nearby cities. Although we use the Puget Sound region to illustrate the effects of these changes, similar policies could be applied in communities across the country.

slideText.value: Many cities use zoning rules to enforce neighborhoods of only single-family housing, which allocates a lot of buildable space to only a small group of people. In many places, it’s illegal to build anything other than a single-family home on more than 75 percent of the residential land.

As a result, cities tend to sprawl out horizontally, incentivizing car use, preventing the development of more affordable apartments, and diminishing the vibrancy of urban neighborhoods. In other cases, multi-family housing is allowed, but at lower densities than current construction, making redevelopment impossible.

But urban land can be used differently. By changing the rules dictating the number of units allowed on a lot, policymakers can encourage the construction of denser housing in their cities, incentivize demand for public transit, reduce pollution, and increase access to a variety of housing types. Here, we detail four zoning changes policymakers can pursue to address housing shortages.

reforms.name: Plexify
reforms.overview: Policymakers could allow two-, three-, or four-flat apartments (also known as duplexes, triplexes, and quadplexes) on parcels currently zoned for single-family homes.

steps.text: With plexified zoning, neighborhoods can become denser, with existing lots transitioning to accommodate more housing units.
New homes can be designed to blend into the neighborhood’s existing environment and allow more affordable price points.

reforms.name: Missing Middle
reforms.overview: Policymakers could also increase the number of units allowed on parcels already zoned for multiple units from 4 or fewer to 12.

steps.text: With more mid-sized multi-family buildings, new housing options become available and predominantly single-family neighborhoods can smoothly transition into denser areas.
These multi-unit buildings could also house businesses or restaurants at the street level, bringing more vitality to the neighborhood.

reforms.name: Multiply
reforms.overview: To dramatically increase housing in areas well-served by transit, policymakers could double the number of allowed housing units within a quarter-mile of transit stations.

steps.text: By doubling unit allowances, policymakers can more quickly meet outsized demand for housing in these highly accessible locations.

Large, multi-family buildings near transit stations also create new opportunities for businesses to bring in local customers, reduce the need for parking since more people can walk to nearby destinations, and serve as the sites for affordable units across income levels.

reforms.name: Legalize
reforms.overview: Beyond rezoning rules for residential lots, policymakers could legalize the construction of multi-family housing on properties currently zoned only for commercial and retail uses.

steps.text: These changes could encourage developers to repurpose surface parking lots into apartment buildings or build mixed-use condominiums atop street-level businesses.
By introducing housing into a commercial center, residents can walk to jobs or stores and policymakers can support a more robust transit system to and from the area.

slideText.value: Each of these zoning changes offers a potential avenue for addressing local housing shortages. By prioritizing multi-family residences, policymakers can increase affordability, drive up demand for public transit, and create more livable areas filled with businesses, restaurants, and jobs just a short walk away.

map.keyTitle: Select a city in the Puget Sound region to see how proposed zoning changes could affect housing density near transit stations.
map.keyText: Stations that exceed 50,000 total units are represented by a wider base and shorter bars for usability. You can learn more about the area around the station by changing the characteristic displayed on the map using the controls on the right ().
map.footnote: Data for each transit station show housing density within a half mile of that station, which can lead to overlap between stations. As a result, housing density data for individual stations should not be summed.

about.value: This interactive tool’s underlying data were developed in association with the Urban Institute report, Making Room for Housing Near Transit: Zoning’s Promise and Barriers, published in January 2023. That report details the methods used to develop the data used in this tool.

To visualize the current and planned transit stations and lines, we leveraged data from Transit Explorer, pulling location data for fixed guideway stations, which are defined as those that are served by bus or rapid transit routes.

For each transit station and its encompassing locality (either municipality or unincorporated county area), we make a series of estimates. We use property-level data assembled from First American Financial Corporation to identify the number of actual housing units (as of 2022) located on parcels within a half-mile, straight-line distance of fixed-guideway transit stations. We did not include parcels with lot sizes of 62,500 square feet or more. We then conduct a series of calculations to assess the number of housing units that could theoretically be built on each of these parcels under current zoning requirements and in the context of potential zoning changes. We made these estimates based on zoning data that we assembled from 39 jurisdictions throughout the Puget Sound region.

We considered four zoning changes. The “Plexify” reform would allow up to four-flat units on lots that currently allow only the construction of single-family residential homes. The “Missing Middle” reform would allow up to 12 units per lot on lots that allow the construction of 3 to 11 units. The “Multiply” reform would double the allowed density of housing units on all lots within a quarter-mile of stations. And the “Legalize” reform would allow large-scale multi-family residential buildings on lots where only commercial, retail, or public uses are currently allowed to be built.

The background of the maps displays demographic or other neighborhood data at the Census tract scale. These data have been drawn from the 2016–20 US Census American Community Survey 5­-year database; the 2019 Census Longitudinal Employer—Household Dynamics database; the 2021 Puget Sound Regional Council’s database of housing; and the 2022 National Housing Preservation Database.
